column2: O nay, O nay, then said our King, O nay, this must not be, To yield to such a rover Myself will not agree; He hath deceived the Frenchman, Likewise the King of Spain, And how can he be true to me, That hath been false to twain?

column2: Probably by this time the greater part of the piratical craft along the Riff coast has been destroyed, and the long-promised Moorish gunboat stationed there to protect foreign shipping.[29] These steps have doubtless been hastened by the fact that the pirates, unfortunately for themselves, attacked a vessel some little time ago belonging to the Sultan of Morocco.
column3: Probably by this time the greater part of the piratical craft along the Riff coast has been destroyed, and the long promised Moorish gunboat stationed there to protect foreign shipping.[twenty nine] These steps have doubtless been hastened by the fact that the pirates, unfortunately for themselves, attacked a vessel some little time ago belonging to the Sultan of Morocco.

column2: For years past the Governments of several European Powers have sought to put friendly pressure upon the Sultan of Morocco to effectually stop the depredations of the Riffian coast pirates.
column3: For years past the Governments of several European Powers have sought to put friendly pressure upon the Sultan of Morocco to effectually stop the depredations of the Riffian coast pirates.

column2: No strong measures, however, were really taken until the above episode occurred.
column3: No strong measures, however, were really taken until the above episode occurred.

column2: It is said that in early days the Moors were some time in accustoming themselves to the perils of the deep.
column3: It is said that in early days the Moors were some time in accustoming themselves to the perils of the deep.

column2: At first they marvelled greatly at "those that go down to the sea in ships, and have their business in great waters," but they did not hasten to follow their example.
column3: At first they marvelled greatly at "those that go down to the sea in ships, and have their business in great waters," but they did not hasten to follow their example.

column2: One eminent ruler of ancient times, in that region, when asked what the sea was like, replied, "The sea is a huge beast which silly folk ride like worms on logs." But it afterwards became clear that the Moors had a strong fancy for the "worms" and "logs" too.
column3: One eminent ruler of ancient times, in that region, when asked what the sea was like, replied, "The sea is a huge beast which silly folk ride like worms on logs." But it afterwards became clear that the Moors had a strong fancy for the "worms" and "logs" too.

column2: They gave up marvelling at those who went to sea, and went on it themselves in search of plunder.
column3: They gave up marvelling at those who went to sea, and went on it themselves in search of plunder.

column2: The risk, the uncertainty, the danger, the sense of superior skill and ingenuity, that attract the adventurous spirit, and the passion for sport, are stated by some writers to have brought such a state of things into existence.
column3: The risk, the uncertainty, the danger, the sense of superior skill and ingenuity, that attract the adventurous spirit, and the passion for sport, are stated by some writers to have brought such a state of things into existence.

column2: One fact seems to be pretty certain, that when these depredations were first made, they took the form of reprisals upon the Spaniards.
column3: One fact seems to be pretty certain, that when these depredations were first made, they took the form of reprisals upon the Spaniards.

column2: No sooner was Granada fallen, than thousands of desperate Moors left the land, disdaining to live under a Spanish yoke.
column3: No sooner was Granada fallen, than thousands of desperate Moors left the land, disdaining to live under a Spanish yoke.

column2: Settling along a portion of the northern coast of Africa, they immediately proceeded to first attack all Spanish vessels that could be found.
column3: Settling along a portion of the northern coast of Africa, they immediately proceeded to first attack all Spanish vessels that could be found.

column2: Their quickness and knowledge of the coasts gave them the opportunity of reprisals for which they longed.
column3: Their quickness and knowledge of the coasts gave them the opportunity of reprisals for which they longed.

column2: Probably this got monotonous in course of time, for in their wild sea courses they took to harrying the vessels belonging to other nations, and so laid the foundation for a race of pirates, which has continued down to quite recently.
column3: Probably this got monotonous in course of time, for in their wild sea courses they took to harrying the vessels belonging to other nations, and so laid the foundation for a race of pirates, which has continued down to quite recently.

column2: As nowadays, the Moors cruised in boats from the commencement of their marauding expeditions.
column3: As nowadays, the Moors cruised in boats from the commencement of their marauding expeditions.

column2: Each man pulled an oar, and knew how to fight as well as row.
column3: Each man pulled an oar, and knew how to fight as well as row.

column2: Drawing little water, a small squadron of these craft could be pushed up almost any creek, or lie hidden behind a rock, till the enemy came in sight.
column3: Drawing little water, a small squadron of these craft could be pushed up almost any creek, or lie hidden behind a rock, till the enemy came in sight.

column2: Then oars out, and a quick stroke for a few minutes.
column3: Then oars out, and a quick stroke for a few minutes.

column2: Next they were alongside their unsuspecting prey, and pouring in a first volley.
column3: Next they were alongside their unsuspecting prey, and pouring in a first volley.

column2: Ultimately the prize was usually taken, the crew put in irons, and the pirates returned home with their capture, no doubt being received with acclamation upon their arrival.
column3: Ultimately the prize was usually taken, the crew put in irons, and the pirates returned home with their capture, no doubt being received with acclamation upon their arrival.

column2: As far back as the sixteenth century the Spanish forts at Alhucemas--not to mention other places--were established for the purpose of repressing piracy in its vicinity.
column3: As far back as the sixteenth century the Spanish forts at Alhucemas-not to mention other places-were established for the purpose of repressing piracy in its vicinity.

column2: Considerable interest is attached to several of the piracies committed during the past few years, as they culminated in strong representations being made to the Sultan of Morocco by the various Governments under whose flag the respective vessels sailed.
column3: Considerable interest is attached to several of the piracies committed during the past few years, as they culminated in strong representations being made to the Sultan of Morocco by the various Governments under whose flag the respective vessels sailed.

column2: Some of them went so far as to send warships to cruise along the Riffian coast.
column3: Some of them went so far as to send warships to cruise along the Riffian coast.

column2: This step apparently had some moral effect upon the pirates, for from that time onwards attacks upon foreign vessels practically ceased. Something more than this, however, was needed, for no one could say how soon the marauding expeditions might be renewed upon a larger scale than ever, so as to make up for lost opportunities.

column2: On August 14, 1897, the Italian three-masted schooner _Fiducia_ was off the coast of Morocco, in the Mediterranean, homeward bound from Pensacola to Marseilles.
column3: On august fourteenth eighteen ninety seven, the Italian three masted schooner underscore Fiducia underscore was off the coast of Morocco, in the Mediterranean, homeward bound from Pensacola to Marseilles.

column2: Here she got becalmed, and while in that condition two boats approached her from the shore.
column3: Here she got becalmed, and while in that condition two boats approached her from the shore.

column2: At first the crew of the _Fiducia_ thought they were native fishing boats.
column3: At first the crew of the underscore Fiducia underscore thought they were native fishing boats.

column2: When, however, the latter got within a hundred yards or so of the helpless vessel, the suspicions of the crew were aroused.
column3: When, however, the latter got within a hundred yards or so of the helpless vessel, the suspicions of the crew were aroused.

column2: The captain warned the Moors not to approach any nearer; a volley of bullets was returned by way of reply, followed by a regular fusillade as the boats advanced.
column3: The captain warned the Moors not to approach any nearer; a volley of bullets was returned by way of reply, followed by a regular fusillade as the boats advanced.

column2: There were only three revolvers on board the schooner, and with these the crew prepared to defend themselves.
column3: There were only three revolvers on board the schooner, and with these the crew prepared to defend themselves.

column2: Soon, however, their supply of ammunition became exhausted, and the pirates boarded the schooner without further opposition.
column3: Soon, however, their supply of ammunition became exhausted, and the pirates boarded the schooner without further opposition.

column2: The vessel was at once ransacked, even the clothes of the crew being taken.
column3: The vessel was at once ransacked, even the clothes of the crew being taken.

column2: The ship's own boat was lowered, and into this the marauders put their booty, and took it ashore, also carrying the captain and one of the crew with them.
column3: The ship's own boat was lowered, and into this the marauders put their booty, and took it ashore, also carrying the captain and one of the crew with them.

column2: About an hour later another boat, containing about twenty pirates, came off and fired on the ship.
column3: About an hour later another boat, containing about twenty pirates, came off and fired on the ship.

column2: The crew, seeing that they could offer no effective resistance, hid themselves away in the hold.
column3: The crew, seeing that they could offer no effective resistance, hid themselves away in the hold.

column2: The other pirates had left very little for the new arrivals to take, and this seemed to annoy them so much that they gave vent to their ill-feelings in several ways, not the least wanton being the pollution of the ship's fresh water.
column3: The other pirates had left very little for the new arrivals to take, and this seemed to annoy them so much that they gave vent to their ill feelings in several ways, not the least wanton being the pollution of the ship's fresh water.

column2: They also smashed the vessel's compass, and tore up the charts. For the next two days the crew existed on a few biscuits, which the pirates had left behind.
column3: They also smashed the vessel's compass, and tore up the charts. For the next two days the crew existed on a few biscuits, which the pirates had left behind.

column2: The following day the British steamship _Oanfa_, of London, hove in sight.
column3: The following day the British steamship underscore Oanfa underscore, of London, hove in sight.

column2: The crew of the schooner hoisted a shirt as a signal, which was fortunately seen, and a boat sent off in response thereto.
column3: The crew of the schooner hoisted a shirt as a signal, which was fortunately seen, and a boat sent off in response thereto.

column2: Assistance was promptly rendered, and the _Fiducia_ put in a position to resume her voyage.
column3: Assistance was promptly rendered, and the underscore Fiducia underscore put in a position to resume her voyage.

column2: In October, 1896, the French barque _Prosper Corue_ was lying becalmed off Alhucemas, a place fortified by the Spaniards to keep the pirates in check, when several boats full of armed Moors seized the vessel and made the crew prisoners.
column3: In October, eighteen ninety six, the French barque underscore Prosper Corue underscore was lying becalmed off Alhucemas, a place fortified by the Spaniards to keep the pirates in check, when several boats full of armed Moors seized the vessel and made the crew prisoners.

column2: They then completely pillaged the ship, removing almost everything of any use or value.
column3: They then completely pillaged the ship, removing almost everything of any use or value.

column2: While the miscreants were thus busily engaged a Spanish merchant steamship, named the _Sevilla_, happened to come along, and was in time to capture one boat and rescue several of the prisoners.
column3: While the miscreants were thus busily engaged a Spanish merchant steamship, named the underscore Sevilla underscore, happened to come along, and was in time to capture one boat and rescue several of the prisoners.

column2: The _Sevilla_ then made towards the barque, but the pirates opened fire on the steamer, killing and wounding some of the crew.
column3: The underscore Sevilla underscore then made towards the barque, but the pirates opened fire on the steamer, killing and wounding some of the crew.

column2: The Spaniard was compelled to retire, leaving the captain of the barque in the hands of the Moors.
column3: The Spaniard was compelled to retire, leaving the captain of the barque in the hands of the Moors.

column2: Subsequently the barque was picked up in an abandoned condition by the British steamship _Oswin_, and towed into Almeria.
column3: Subsequently the barque was picked up in an abandoned condition by the British steamship underscore Oswin underscore, and towed into Almeria.

column2: An arrangement was afterwards made with the pirates to release the captains of the _Fiducia_ and the Portuguese barque _Rosita Faro_--a much earlier capture--and some members of both crews, in exchange for the Riffians captured by the Spanish steamer _Sevilla_ and a ransom of 3,000 dollars.

column2: It was only after prolonged negotiations and a large sum of money that a French warship succeeded in obtaining the freedom of the captain of the _Prosper Corue_ and a few other Frenchmen.
column3: It was only after prolonged negotiations and a large sum of money that a French warship succeeded in obtaining the freedom of the captain of the underscore Prosper Corue underscore and a few other Frenchmen.

column2: For some reason or other, the pirates seemed very much disinclined to part with these prisoners.

column2: Only a short time before the attack on the French barque took place, a notice was issued by the British Board of Trade, in which the attention of ship-owners and masters of vessels was called to the dangers attending navigation off the coast of Morocco.

column2: The document then proceeded to detail the case of the British schooner _Mayer_, of Gibraltar, which was boarded about 10 miles from the Riff coast by twenty Moors armed with rifles and daggers. As usual, the pirates ransacked the vessel, destroyed the ensign and ship's papers, brutally assaulted the men on board, and then made off in their boat.

column2: Again, there is the Spanish cutter _Jacob_.
column3: Again, there is the Spanish cutter underscore Jacob underscore.

column2: She was running along the Moorish coast one fine summer's evening a few years since, when a boat full of pirates suddenly came alongside, and speedily upset the quietness which had previously reigned on board the _Jacob_.
column3: She was running along the Moorish coast one fine summer's evening a few years since, when a boat full of pirates suddenly came alongside, and speedily upset the quietness which had previously reigned on board the underscore Jacob underscore.

column2: Five of the crew managed to escape in the cutter's boat and were picked up some days later by a passing vessel.

column2: Fortunately the weather continued fine, and the _Jacob_ drifted towards the Spanish coast, where she was seen and assistance promptly rendered.

column2: He left Gibraltar in command of the barque _San Antonio_ for Alhucemas, and when about six miles from Penon de la Gomera a boat manned by thirteen Moors was observed to be approaching the vessel.

column2: Next morning the _San Antonio_ was seen drifting out to sea, and the captain, who was afraid of being put to death, suggested that he should go on board and bring her back to the anchorage.

column2: Probably thinking that some of their comrades were on the barque, but unable to set the necessary canvas to return, only two Moors were sent off with the captain, and these remained in the boat when the vessel was reached. column2: It is sincerely to be hoped that the Sultan of Morocco is carrying out his task in such a manner as will induce the inhabitants of the Riff coast to follow some occupation in future which is more likely to be appreciated by those who have to navigate vessels in the Mediterranean. Previous to stern measures being taken by the Sultan, it was not at all uncommon for his envoys to the native tribes--for the purpose of obtaining the release of captives--to be received with derision.
column3: It is sincerely to be hoped that the Sultan of Morocco is carrying out his task in such a manner as will induce the inhabitants of the Riff coast to follow some occupation in future which is more likely to be appreciated by those who have to navigate vessels in the Mediterranean. Previous to stern measures being taken by the Sultan, it was not at all uncommon for his envoys to the native tribes-for the purpose of obtaining the release of captives-to be received with derision.

column2: Often, too, they were maltreated to such an extent that they were glad to escape with their lives.

column2: Some of the neighboring tribes continually endeavored to purchase captives for the pleasure of killing them, but it is satisfactory to learn that no sales are recorded, as the anticipated ransom was always largely in excess of the sums offered by the bloodthirsty natives.
